definitions.definition: Originally, one's oath or word of honour, given as a condition of release from custody; now specifically, describing the release of a former prisoner under certain conditions, especially the promise of good behaviour.
examples: He will be on parole for nearly two more years.

definitions.definition: Conditional release of a prisoner (now especially before the end of a custodial sentence ), or the term or state of such release; the system governing such releases.
A word of honor, especially given by a prisoner of war , to not engage in combat if released.
A watchword or code phrase; ( military ) a password given only to officers , distinguished from the countersign , which is given to all guards.
Language in use, as opposed to language as a system.
The permission for a foreigner who does not meet the technical requirements for a visa to be allowed to enter the U.S. on humanitarian grounds.

main_definition: ( with on ) Originally, one's oath or word of honour, given as a condition of release from custody; now specifically, describing the release of a former prisoner under certain conditions, especially the promise of good behaviour. [from 17th c.]
secondary_definitions: Conditional release of a prisoner (now especially before the end of a custodial sentence ), or the term or state of such release; the system governing such releases. [from 17th c.]
( now historical ) A word of honor, especially given by a prisoner of war , to not engage in combat if released. [from 17th c.]
( now rare ) A watchword or code phrase; ( military ) a password given only to officers , distinguished from the countersign , which is given to all guards. [from 18th c.]
( linguistics ) Language in use, as opposed to language as a system. [from 20th c.]
( US , immigration law ) The permission for a foreigner who does not meet the technical requirements for a visa to be allowed to enter the U.S. on humanitarian grounds.
